title: 114_hr4178
content: The "American Unemployed Worker Investment Act of 2015" extends the Work Opportunity Tax Credit until December 31, 2017. Employers hiring individuals receiving unemployment compensation may be eligible for a tax credit. The "American Unemployed Worker Investment Act of 2015" extends the Work Opportunity Tax Credit until December 31, 2017, allowing employers hiring individuals receiving unemployment compensation to be eligible for a tax credit. Section 51(d)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new category of qualified unemployment compensation recipients for small business employers. The "American Unemployed Worker Investment Act of 2015" extends the Work Opportunity Tax Credit until December 31, 2017, allowing small business employers to receive a tax credit for hiring individuals who have been receiving unemployment compensation. The new category of qualified unemployment compensation recipients must meet specific criteria to be eligible for the tax credit. The tax credit for hiring individuals who have been receiving unemployment compensation is extended until December 31, 2017. Employers with 10 to 25 full-time equivalent employees can receive a maximum credit of $4,000 per employee. The credit is denied unless the individual is employed full-time for 1 year. Section 51(i)(3) of the Code is amended to include special rules for qualified unemployment compensation recipients. No wages will be considered for tax credit unless the individual works at least 35 hours per week for a year and increases the employer's full-time equivalent employees by 1 for at least a year. Section 3111(e) of the Code is amended to replace "Qualified Veterans" with "Qualified Individuals" and define "qualified individual" as a qualified veteran or a qualified unemployment recipient. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who start working for the employer after the enactment of this Act, including qualified unemployment compensation recipients.
